answer_html: \({\color{blue}\frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\cdot (-r \sin(t)) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \cdot r \cos(t)}.\)
answer_latex: ${\color{blue}\frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\cdot (-r \sin(t)) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \cdot r \cos(t)}.$
hints_html: To evaluate this partial derivative we need to use the chain rule.
hints_latex: To evaluate this partial derivative we need to use the chain rule.
hints_raw: To evaluate this partial derivative we need to use the <b>chain rule</b>.
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
The variable z is a function of both x, y which, in turn, are both functions of t. Thus, any change in z in response to a change in t will be the result of how x and y change with t. We can write the derivative of z with respect to t using the chain rule:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial t}\end{aligned}\]

We evaluate the partial derivatives of x, y with respect to t:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial x}{\partial t} = -r \sin(t), \quad \frac{\partial y}{\partial t} = r \cos(t).\end{aligned}\]

And thus,

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}\frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\cdot (-r \sin(t)) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \cdot r \cos(t)}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The variable ''z'' is a function of both ''x'', ''y'' which, in turn, are both functions of ''t''. Thus, any change in ''z'' in response to a change in ''t'' will be the result of how ''x'' and ''y'' change with ''t''. We can write the derivative of ''z'' with respect to ''t'' using the <b>chain rule</b>:
:<math>
\frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\frac{\partial x}{\partial t} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\frac{\partial y}{\partial t}
</math>
We evaluate the partial derivatives of ''x'', ''y'' with respect to ''t'':
:<math>
\frac{\partial x}{\partial t} = -r \sin(t), \quad \frac{\partial y}{\partial t} = r \cos(t).
</math>
And thus,
:<math>
{\color{blue}
\frac{\partial z}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\cdot (-r \sin(t)) + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \cdot r \cos(t)}.
</math>
statement_html:
Suppose z = f(x,y) has continuous second order partial derivatives and x = r cos(t), y = r sin(t). Express the following partial derivatives in terms of r,t and the partial derivatives of f.

a)

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial z}{\partial t}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Suppose z = f(x,y) has continuous second order partial derivatives and x = r cos(t), y = r sin(t). Express the following partial derivatives in terms of r,t and the partial derivatives of f.

<b>  a)</b> 
:<math>\frac{\partial z}{\partial t}</math>
